awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Advancing Sustainable Systems and Environmental Technologies to Serve Humanity (ASSETs to Serve Humanity)
awd_abstract_narration:
This new three-year Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site Program, Advancing Sustainable Systems and Environmental Technologies to Serve Humanity (ASSETs to Serve Humanity) will build upon an 18 year history of successful REU Site programs in Environmental Sciences and Engineering at Clarkson University. The program will offer a diverse cohort of undergraduate students the opportunity to engage in research to advance multidisciplinary approaches needed to address national emerging issues of energy supply and environmental quality.  Achieving environmental sustainability and resilience to changing global conditions requires technological advancement produced by globally-competent engineers and scientists capable of adapting to the challenges of environmental, social, and cultural change. This program will advance multidisciplinary approaches needed to address national emerging issues of energy supply and environmental quality. Twenty faculty members from ten departments in the sciences, engineering, social sciences, and humanities will provide integrated sustainability education, graduate training, and hands-on interdisciplinary research opportunities that spark the imaginations of young minds towards production of a STEM workforce of future engineers and actionable leaders on environmental sustainability.  

Clarkson's Institute for a Sustainable Environment will host 10 REU students over a 10-week summer program where they will be immersed in a broad array of projects led by accomplished and dedicated faculty mentors who will ensure meaningful experiences for all REU participants. Undergraduate researchers will work with graduate students and faculty mentors, participate in research group meetings, present their work at a University-wide undergraduate research symposium, write a final report, and be encouraged to publish their work with their mentor in peer-reviewed publications. Program objectives are designed to widen educational pathways towards science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) careers, to serve traditionally underrepresented students and students from institutions with limited research opportunities, to develop engineers and scientists prepared to meet future challenges, and to teach students to effectively communicate scientific research to shape effective policy.  Environmental leadership is promoted through professional development activities and transformative research in sustainable and resilient energy and infrastructure, sensing, identifying, and mitigating emerging pollutants and other risks, and transformation of social policy and behaviors related to infrastructure, energy, and the environment. Through this high degree of research dissemination, participants in the REU Site program at Clarkson University drive technological innovation needed to maintain public well-being in a more crowded and resource-limited world, and to improve the economic competitiveness of the United States.

por.por_cntn:
The Theme of this NSF REU Site Program at Clarkson University was Advancing Sustainable Systems and Environmental Technologies to Serve Humanity (ASSETs to Serve Humanity). Through this program, we advanced multidisciplinary approaches needed to address societal needs of our growing global populace. We promoted leadership through professional development activities and research experiences in sustainable and resilient energy and other infrastructure, detection and mitigation of emerging pollutants and other risks, and social policy related to infrastructure, energy, and environment. The objectives of the program included the following:

  1. Improve pathways to advanced science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) education by preparing students and motivating them to continue on to graduate school.
  2. Serve traditionally underrepresented students and students from colleges and universities lacking research opportunities in STEM fields by providing opportunities to conduct research in interdisciplinary engineering and science in a supportive and challenging atmosphere.
  3. Develop a STEM workforce of actionable leaders on environmental sustainability by providing opportunities to learn and practice skills necessary to address societal challenges of the 21st century through cross-disciplinary training and experience in hypothesis-driven and applied research.
  4. Teach students to effectively communicate scientific research that shapes future policy by providing training in oral, written, and interpersonal communication, and ample opportunities to practice these skills through professional presentation, peer-reviewed publication, and personal interactions with a diverse group of research students and faculty mentors.

 

Intellectual Merit

This REU Site program engaged 40 undergraduate research students from institutions across the United States and Puerto Rico in cutting-edge research at Clarkson University. Students received formal education in sustainability as related to their research projects and explored first-hand examples of sustainability practices in industry and the environment from moderate to extensive in implementation. All students were trained in preparing and delivering research presentations; for many of these students, it was their first scientific presentation. Projects completed by REU participants included both research and development activities. Examples include development of cold plasma-based reactors for removal of difficult to treat chemicals from water to development of aquaculture practices that remove nutrients from polluted coastal systems while providing economic opportunities for those traditionally employed in the fishing, lobstering, or other industries in the Northeastern United States. Of the 31 REU participants that have graduated from their degree programs as of the date of this report, 55% have already entered graduate study and 45% have entered professional careers, most with the intent of returning to graduate study.  

 

Broader Impacts

With the theme of sustainability, this REU Site program operated through Clarkson University’s multidisciplinary Institute for a Sustainable Environment. Students were engaged in cross-disciplinary research in the sciences, engineering, humanities, and economics, broadening student experiences and capabilities for research on complex ideas that transcend disciplinary boundaries. Students were engaged in social policy conversations and technical research and development workshops that improved their understanding of the complexities of designing a sustainable future. Through this mechanism, not only do future engineers benefit from a broader world-view, but other disciplines including the humanities, social sciences, and economics benefit from improved translation and valuation of core research products. Beyond disciplinary diversity, this REU Site program provided opportunities for cutting-edge research to students both traditionally underrepresented in the sciences and engineering and those who study at institutions lacking research opportunities for undergraduates. We had strong participation of women in sciences and engineering projects (72.5%). Greater than 38% of our participants were students of racial or ethnic groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences, technology, engineering and mathematics fields. Nearly 48% of our participants were from institutions lacking opportunities for undergraduate research experience. Improved pathways to professional engineering and science careers for those otherwise underrepresented improves the diversity of viewpoints in engineering design and scientific inquiry that result in infrastructure, technology, and policies that better reflect the diversity of viewpoints and experiences within our populace.
